709254f-b.title: Manhattan : 6th Avenue  - Watts Street.
709254f-b.text:
(1)
Sixth Avenue, west side, north from and including Watts Street, along the line of and including the former Clark Street, which has been absorbed by Sixth Avenue. No. 40 Watts Street, which used to be two doors from the N.W. corner of Sullivan and Watts Streets, is now practically at the N.W. corner of Sixth Avenue.
1932.
J. Clarence Davies Collection, Museum of the City of New York.
Negative No. 305.
(2)
The same during the extension of Sixth Ave. Note the political banners upon the fire escapes of No. 46. They depict the Democratic presidential candidates, Alfred E. Smith and William T. Robinson.

October 19, 1928.
P. L. Sperr
709254f-b.folder: Manhattan : 6th Avenue  & Watts Street., Manhattan, NY

709255f-a.title: Manhattan : 6th Avenue - Watts Street.
709255f-a.text:
Sixth Ave. (Extension), east side, south from and including Watts Street. The house on the extreme left, is No. 47 Sullivan Street.
October 19, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
709255f-a.folder: Manhattan : 6th Avenue & Watts Street., Manhattan, NY

724293f-a.text:
53 to 61 Watts Street, south side, between Sixth Ave. Extension and Varick Street, showing three 5-story tenements (Nos. 57-61) under demolition. These adjoin the 10-story structure (extreme right) at the S.E. corner of this street and Varick Street. The two 3-story buildings are frame construction with brick fronts and are east of the latter.
October 18, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
